failures.suggestSolution: Regularly inspect and replace spark plugs and ignition components; ensure proper fuel system maintenance.
Immediately address engine misfires and rich fuel conditions; repair any exhaust leaks to protect the catalytic converter.
Secure wiring harnesses properly; promptly replace damaged wheel speed sensors or wiring, and address bearing issues.
Do not ignore ABS or brake warning lights; seek immediate professional inspection for any braking system malfunctions.
Ensure all airbag system wiring connectors are secure; avoid physical damage to components and follow all safety protocols.
Adhere to oil change schedules and use the correct oil type/viscosity; promptly address low oil pressure warnings.
Maintain a healthy vehicle battery and charging system; get persistent communication fault codes professionally diagnosed.
Ensure all aftermarket electrical installations are professional; maintain overall electrical system health to prevent module communication failures.

badPractices.descriptionBadPractice: Ignoring routine spark plug replacement, neglecting ignition coil or wire wear, or poor fuel system maintenance (e.g., old fuel filter, faulty fuel pump).
Neglecting engine misfires, running with rich fuel mixtures, or ignoring exhaust leaks, which all contribute to premature catalytic converter failure.
Not securing wiring harnesses, allowing physical damage to wheel speed sensor wiring, or ignoring signs of a damaged wheel bearing (which can affect the reluctor ring).
Driving with persistent ABS/brake system warning lights, ignoring intermittent brake system malfunctions, or exposing the ABS module/wiring to excessive moisture or physical impact.
Improperly reconnecting wiring connectors under seats after maintenance or cleaning, physical damage to airbag wiring, or incorrectly replacing airbag system components.
Ignoring persistent low oil pressure warnings, using incorrect oil viscosity, or neglecting oil changes which can lead to sensor fouling or failure due to sludge buildup.
Ignoring battery and charging system issues (low voltage), improper electrical repairs leading to poor connections or damaged wiring, or not addressing other related communication fault codes.

Exposing vehicle wiring to damage (e.g., during aftermarket installations), neglecting battery issues that cause low voltage to modules, or ignoring signs of module malfunction like power window or door lock failures.

report.title: Low system voltage
report.description: Check the speed sensor in the transmission.
report.suggestedSolution: It may require replacement if damaged.

report.title: Low coolant temperature
report.suggestedSolution: If it’s stuck open, it needs to be replaced.

report.title: Low oil pressure
report.description: Check the oil level and pressure sensor.
report.suggestedSolution: Do not continue driving if the problem persists. Take the vehicle to a workshop immediately.

report.title: Fuel sensor out of range
report.description: Check the fuel tank float or sensor.

technical_errors.suggestion: Check the speed sensor in the transmission. It may require replacement if damaged.
Check the oil level and pressure sensor. Do not continue driving if the problem persists. Take the vehicle to a workshop immediately.
Check the engine thermostat. If it’s stuck open, it needs to be replaced.
Check the fuel tank float or sensor. It could be stuck.

quick_diagnosis.resultSummary: The vehicle is currently in good condition. However, over time, there may be significant failures in the electrical system or power steering.

failuresTemplate.name: Spark plug failure
failuresTemplate.description: The spark plugs are worn out, causing the engine to misfire and run roughly. This can lead to reduced fuel efficiency and increased emissions. Ignoring this issue may result in further engine damage

failuresTemplate.name: Overheating engine
failuresTemplate.description: The engine temperature has exceeded safe limits, risking severe internal damage. This often results from coolant leaks or a faulty thermostat. Prolonged overheating may lead to engine failure.

failuresTemplate.name: Low oil pressure
failuresTemplate.description: Oil pressure is below the recommended level, risking insufficient lubrication of engine components. This can cause increased friction and rapid engine wear. Continuing to drive may result in engine seizure.

failuresTemplate.name: Battery voltage low
failuresTemplate.description: The battery voltage has dropped below the required threshold, which can cause starting issues and electrical malfunctions. This may be due to an old battery or alternator problems. Persistent low voltage can leave you stranded.

failuresTemplate.name: Loose fuel cap
failuresTemplate.description: The fuel cap is not properly tightened, allowing fuel vapors to escape. This can trigger the check engine light and reduce fuel efficiency. Over time, it may damage the emissions system.

failuresTemplate.name: Transmission slipping
failuresTemplate.description: The transmission is not shifting gears smoothly, which can cause jerking or loss of power. This may result from low transmission fluid or worn components. Ignoring the issue can lead to costly repairs.

failuresTemplate.name: EGR valve fault
failuresTemplate.description: The EGR valve is malfunctioning, leading to increased emissions and reduced engine performance. This can cause rough idling and engine knocking. Prolonged issues may damage the catalytic converter.

failuresTemplate.name: Mass airflow sensor error
failuresTemplate.description: The mass airflow sensor is providing incorrect readings, affecting the air-fuel mixture. This can cause poor acceleration and stalling. If left unresolved, it may damage the engine.

failuresTemplate.name: Catalytic converter efficiency low
failuresTemplate.description: The catalytic converter is not operating efficiently, leading to increased emissions. This can result in a failed emissions test and reduced engine performance. Continued driving may cause further engine issues.

failuresTemplate.name: Wheel speed sensor failure
failuresTemplate.description: A wheel speed sensor is not functioning, which can disable ABS and traction control systems. This increases the risk of skidding during braking. The issue may also trigger warning lights on the dashboard.

failuresTemplate.name: Coolant temperature sensor fault
failuresTemplate.description: The coolant temperature sensor is giving inaccurate readings, which can affect engine performance and fuel efficiency. This may cause the engine to overheat or run too cold. Persistent faults can damage the engine.

failuresTemplate.name: Brake fluid low
failuresTemplate.description: Brake fluid levels are below the safe minimum, reducing braking effectiveness. This can increase stopping distances and risk of accidents. Leaks or worn brake components may be the cause.

failuresTemplate.name: Tire pressure low
failuresTemplate.description: One or more tires have low pressure, which can affect handling and fuel economy. Driving with underinflated tires increases the risk of blowouts. It also causes uneven tire wear.

failuresTemplate.name: Alternator failure
failuresTemplate.description: The alternator is not charging the battery properly, leading to electrical issues and potential stalling. This can leave you stranded if the battery depletes. Warning lights may appear on the dashboard.

failuresTemplate.name: Fuel pump malfunction
failuresTemplate.description: The fuel pump is not delivering adequate fuel to the engine, causing hesitation or stalling. This can make starting the car difficult. Prolonged issues may damage the engine.

failuresTemplate.name: Throttle position sensor error
failuresTemplate.description: The throttle position sensor is sending inconsistent signals, affecting acceleration and engine response. This can cause surging or hesitation while driving. Ignoring the issue may lead to unsafe driving conditions.

bad_practices.description: Ignoring early symptoms like strange noises or smells.
